discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
HDMI: Audio and video signal, best for TV to PC connections
Answer should be C. 1,200W modular power supply, how can an uninterruptible power supply fit into a ATX case?

comments.content: MIKE NEED HELP CONTACT ME +264812475374 OR ANYONE
if MikeNg98 needs HELP ..... what is your Answer then?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A video production workstation that will consist of two high-end GPUs will require a lot of power and a modular power supply. A modular power supply allows the technician to connect only the cables that are needed for the components, which reduces clutter and improves airflow. A 1,200W power supply should be enough to power the two GPUs and other components, but the exact wattage depends on the specifications of the GPUs and other components. A 400W external power supply is not enough to power the workstation and may not be compatible with the ATX case. Two 600W redundant power supplies are unnecessary and may not fit in the ATX case. A 1,500W uninterruptible power supply (UPS) is a device that provides backup power in case of a power outage, but it is not a replacement for a power supply unit (PSU). References: https://www.comptia.org/blog/what-is-a-power-supply-unit
The correct answer is D.

Selected Answer: C
D cannot be correct. A UPS does not provide any ATX power sources for the computer.

Selected Answer: C
Not A since using high-end GPU; Not B since resuing ATX case; Not D since doesn't mention the need of availability.

Selected Answer: C
Two high-end GPUs can easily draw over 500W of power each. Therefore, a 1,200W power supply is the minimum required to power the workstation. A modular power supply is also a good choice, as it allows the technician to only install the cables that are needed, which reduces clutter and improves airflow.

Selected Answer: C
C. 

Because of ATX case.

C. 1,200W modular power supply
Not UPS

questions.question_text: A technician is building a video production workstation that will consist of two high-end GPUs. The technician is reusing an existing ATX case. Which of the following should the technician select as the MOST appropriate power supply type?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Since the printing output has been cut off, the job should be printed on longer paper. The next step should ensure the longer paper being used. Therefore, not D since D still use shorter paper. Not C since the problem is not about paper alignment (it's cut-off). Not B since we need to verfity which printer tray should be used before we make the swap (otherwise we might need to do lot of testing to find out the correct setting)
I think A is the best answer, D if it was a constant problem, as I understood the question.
The correct answer is C

Selected Answer: A
The technician should first verify that the printing trays are correctly set. This includes checking the paper size, orientation, and source. If the printing trays are not correctly set, the printer may not be able to feed the paper properly, which could result in the bottom of the print job being cut off.

Selected Answer: A
ChatGPT said A

Selected Answer: A
Since the issue only occurs when printing from a specific paper tray with a specific paper size, the technician should start by verifying that the paper tray is set up correctly. The printer may be detecting a different paper size or type than the one actually loaded in the tray, causing the print job to be cut off at the bottom.

To verify that the paper tray is set up correctly, the technician should check the following:

Ensure that the paper size and type settings for the tray match the actual paper loaded in the tray.
Check that the paper guides in the tray are set snugly against the paper.
Make sure that the tray is not overloaded with paper, which can cause misfeeds and other paper handling issues.
After verifying the paper tray settings, the technician can run a test print job to see if the issue has been resolved. If the problem persists, the technician can try other troubleshooting steps such as checking for paper jams, cleaning the paper path, or resetting the printer's default settings.

Selected Answer: A
You should verify that the paper tray is set up correctly for the paper size and type specified in the print job. This includes checking the guides that hold the paper in place to ensure that they are correctly set for the paper size and that the paper is aligned correctly within the tray. Resetting the default to use 8.5in x 11in paper (option D) is not recommended as it would change the paper size for all print jobs, rather than addressing the specific issue with 8.5in x 14in paper.

Selected Answer: D
I think its D too just because we had similar issue at my job.

Selected Answer: D
I believe D is the right answer. Simply adjusting the needful paper settings would fix this problem.
This answer, like so many others, makes no sense.

questions.question_text: A printer technician receives a support request for a laser printer that sometimes cuts off the bottom of the print job. During troubleshooting, the technician notices that affected jobs are set for 8.5in x 14in (216mm x 356mm) paper and only print from a particular paper tray. Which of the following actions should the technician perform NEXT?

choices.B: Swap printer trays until the print jobs complete as expected
choices.D: Reset the default to use 8.5in x 11in (216mm x 279mm) paper
choices.C: Replace the tray rollers to ensure proper paper alignment
choices.A: Verify that the printing trays are correctly set

choices.B: The CPU heat sink was attached without adequate thermal paste
choices.C: The SSD drives do not have enough Pagefile
choices.D: The system does not have enough RAM for 4K video
choices.A: The video card was installed in the wrong PCIe slot

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Thermal paste is a substance that fills in any gaps between a CPU and its heat sink, which is a device that dissipates heat from the CPU. Without adequate thermal paste, the CPU may overheat and cause the system to shut down automatically to prevent damage. This is especially likely when running 4K video or games, which are more demanding and generate more heat. The technician should check if the CPU heat sink was attached
 
properly and apply enough thermal paste to ensure good contact and heat transfer. Reference: https://partners. comptia.org/docs/default-source/resources/a-core-series-combined-content-guide (page 28)

The most likely cause of the immediate shutdown when running demanding tasks like 4K video or gaming is B. The CPU heat sink was attached without adequate thermal paste.

Insufficient thermal paste can lead to overheating of the CPU, which can trigger automatic shutdowns to prevent damage.

Here's why the other options are less likely:

A. The video card was installed in the wrong PCIe slot: While this could cause performance issues or compatibility problems, it's less likely to cause immediate shutdowns.
C. The SSD drives do not have enough Pagefile: Pagefile is used for virtual memory, which is less critical for tasks like 4K video playback and gaming.
D. The system does not have enough RAM for 4K video: Insufficient RAM could lead to performance issues and stuttering, but it's unlikely to cause immediate shutdowns.
Therefore, the technician should first check the CPU's thermal paste application and ensure it's properly seated with adequate thermal paste.

GG

Selected Answer: B
I think its B. The other answers just are not correct. B while unlikey in my expereince is at least possibel. Not enough RAM = Slow computer. No room for paging file = Slow Computer. Graphics card somehow (not even sure how that could actually happen!) in wrong slot = No graphics.

Selected Answer: B
A silvery-gray substance that you apply to a processor before installing a cooling solution. It allows for an efficient transfer of heat from the IHS of the processor to the base plate or water block of the CPU cooler that is designed to dissipate that heat.

comments.content: The system works until 4k video is turned on then it goes off immediately. correct me if am wrong shouldn't D be the answer. I believe the B answer will allow the 4k video start but goes off after a while, the immediate switching off of the system to me points to RAM
I was thinking this too, but the cpu probably spikes in temp fairly quickly when using 4k video or gaming. So it probably does shut down what feels like immediately.
I take this back.. yes most likely thermal paste
that's why I would go with A, CPU overheating will not happen immediately. This could be short circuit by not installing GPU card correctly

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Among all four choices, B is the closest one. In reality, I will check the power supply first since overheating CPU takes longer time to shutdown than lack of power

questions.question_text: A user built a new PC with parts sourced from a popular online vendor. The system boots to the OS and basic browsing works, but whenever the user opens a 4K video or starts to play a game, the system immediately shuts down. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of this issue?

A technician recently received a written warning for causing a system-wide outage. The outage was a result of an unscheduled patch being manually pushed during production hours. Which of the following could have MOST likely prevented the technician from receiving the warning?

discussion.content:
A is the best answer
Following corporate procedures would have been the most likely factor that could have prevented the technician from receiving the written warning. Following established procedures, such as change management, helps ensure that changes made to the production environment are thoroughly tested, approved, and implemented in a controlled and safe manner, reducing the risk of system-wide outages and other unintended consequences.

Selected Answer: A
"written warning for causing a system-wide outage. The outage was a result of an unscheduled patch being manually pushed during production hours" directly indicates that the technician did NOT know the procedure. Even if the technician tested before pushing the update through manually, he still would have made the error of doing it during production hours so it cannot be B. Testing is important, but in this scenario would still result in a mistake being made

Selected Answer: B
Agree with Com since you definitely need to test every patch/update/driver whatsoever before push to company wide, it is ok to have one single affected testing machine

Its A. YOu MUST follow procedures (if they exist). Pusing through a patch during production hours is a massive NoNo. YOu just dont do that unless its a desperate Malware attack situation for example. Follow the Proceedures which would almost certainly involve Testing BUT testing is only a part of it

Selected Answer: B
I think B makes more sense since the technician should have tested the patch before releasing it. while A is a valid choice too nothing indicates the technician didn't follow the policy procedure.

This should be A. If they would have tested, they would have seen the outage happen in a nonproduction environment.
